channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for MI
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for MI

item.title: Report E-2025050464
item.description:
Report E-2025050464

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-10T03:46:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-22
  • City: BATTLE CREEK
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 22, 2025, one (1) 2,222-pound super-sack of sodium chlorate powder was ripped by a bolt in transit and released approximately one (1) cup of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from SET Environmental (SET) to remediate the site. The crew patched the supersack with tape and shrink wrap for further handling by R+L. SET personnel utilized hand tools to collect all released powder as well as any miscellaneous clean up debris in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025050281
item.description:
Report E-2025050281

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-10T03:46:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-23
  • City: JACKSON
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately five (5) ounces of material released from one (1) 5-gallon metal pail due to a loose lid prior to arrival causing the pail to leak. No surfaces were affected by the leak, just the pail. No granular absorbents were needed. The damaged pail was placed into one (1) 25-gallon plastic drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.
